is the desecration of their sacrifices. 
 
 Hundreds of thousands of US soldiers died to protect our freedoms, yet the House and a relative few Americans support stripping the country of those rights. They died to ensure that we would be free. How can anyone who supports the troops even consider legislation that would make their sacrifices in vain? 
 
 For those who claim they support the troops on the right, they sure don't seem to have problems desecrating, defiling, violating and ignoring the sacrifices of hundreds of thousands of US troops.

 1st article does not say what percentage of veterans become homeless. only that of the homeless veterans, what percentage served in what war and for how long.
 
 2nd-4th article
 i take this to mean pyschology is a greater risk factor for being homeless than being a vet.
 that while there may be association between psychological trauma of being a soldier, this seems to be addressed with greater psychological preparation before and after returning from combat operations.
 and that access to medical care and social support system is greater now than before.
 
Peter Dougherty, director of Homeless Veterans Programs at the VA, said services for veterans at risk of becoming homeless have improved exponentially since the Vietnam era. Over the past 30 years, the VA has expanded from 170 hospitals, adding 850 clinics and 206 veteran centers with an increasing emphasis on mental health. The VA also supports around 300 homeless veteran centers like the ones run by U.S.VETS, a partially non-profit organization.

 
 last article
 
The United States Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) estimates that on a given night some 250,000 veterans are homeless nationwide, and that as many as half a million veterans experience homeless in the course of a year; this represents around two percent of all living American veterans. All but 3 percent of homeless veterans are men, and 56 percent are black or Latino. Approximately 45 percent suffer from mental illness, and more than two-thirds suffer from substance abuse disorders. More than two-thirds of homeless veterans served in the armed forces for at least three years, and 47 percent served in the Vietnam War.

 2% of the vet population. yes this is 2 too high but never the less, at any point in time, only 1% are actually homeless. 
 
 while we certainly should be taking better care of our vets
 i hardly see this as "taking a XXXX" on our vets

Well, the thing I can't stand is that when soldiers return from a combat zone, after risking their lives defending their country, that some of them lose their jobs and become homeless. To me that's unforgivable.
 IMO those employers which are responsible for such acts should be severely punished by the American government.
 These soldiers were willing to pay the ultimate price and do things that nobody else wanted to do, yet some of them got the shaft. This ****** me off immensely.
 
 I also posted the articles to show that it's not just Vietnam veterans that got the short end of the stick. About 10% of the homeless veterans are soldiers that served in the Gulf War. This is about 25.000 permanently homeless and 50.000 'partially' homeless.
 The US had a total of 500.000 troops in the Gulf. Let's say for arguments sake that all 500.000 troops were rotated once*, so that makes 1.000.000 troops.
 So 2,5% of the soldiers that served in the Gulf became homeless and 5% of the soldiers that served in the Gulf became 'partially' homeless.
 To me that number is way too high.
 
 
 * Active combat units probably had a higher troop rotation than the units in the rear with the gear, and some of the soldiers probably had more than one tour, but for arguments sake I averaged it out.
